column1: Will Boom Technology's XB-1 supersonic aircraft complete a successful test flight before 2022?
column6: ['Business', 'Technology']
From a recent (Dec 20) piece in Wired (https://www.wired.com/story/boom-supersonic-planes/ ):
Almost no chance no more.
They have announced they will not.
Adjusting for time remaining
"we’re not flying yet (lots of ground testing left). But XB-1 did hit a major pre-flight test milestone today [Nov 21]"
Passage of time.
Its virgin they aint tge fastest horse in the corral but they will get there. not to mention economic conditions are holding back everything
Nothing has been announced by now, which makes the probability of it happening by the end of the year zero. They would want a lot of publicity long before the flight.
Unless covid delays it
I could be surprised, but that would surprise me.
Passage of time, no changes. I guess new developments could surprise me, but I'd be surprised.
Next week on 60 Minutes: Supersonic passenger planes, shows the actual test plain in the hanger, not eve close https://www.cbsnews.com/video/next-week-on-60-minutes-supersonic-passenger-planes/

They've just been named on Time's best inventions of 2021 (1), which is a nice touch and bodes well for the company's future, but given the time to the end of the year, I don't think it's likely they will launch a test flight in 2021 (can you imagine asking test pilots to take the risk just before Christmas?)
Passage of time.
Passage of time
Short (5 mins) video by CBS: "successful test flights, next year [...]" (~ 0:49) https://twitter.com/cbsmornings/status/1451899857069817859
Less confident. Cannot find anything recent to suggest this is on course. Maybe early 2022 is the plan now.
Passage of time.

Must be really tiring for the CEO to go out there and bullshit every day. Its twitter is also filled with fairly inane content. I also think that they wouldn't be talking all that much about carbon neutral flight if they had more exciting things to talk about, such as a working prototype. Going down. https://www.voanews.com/a/supersonic-commercial-air-travel-to-return-by-end-of-decade/6257871.html https://boomsupersonic.com/flyby/ https://twitter.com/boomaero
I believe that the test will need into ‘22 to complete arrangements
3 months left and it seems like there's nothing planned. No news on this and I would think an upcoming test would be of media interest.
According to a Sep 18 report by Fortune, "The prototype [...] should take its first test-flight early next year": https://archive.is/4NlCX#selection-599.221-599.328
Tweak
-1% on passage of time.

These things seem to get held up. Base rate for experimental planes seems to be a slow release. Other hand: Scaled Composites do prototype planes,, they seems to have a rate of 1 new plane every 2 years or so. So this makes me a little more bullish.(having said that making prototype planes is their bread and butter). Seems a lot of new tech in this plane, different from normal planes. On other hand, this is a scaled down prototype. I am unaware of any engine testing. - assume there is some stress testing required. Planes are complex, everything has to be right, all they need is one hard issue to hold them up. It's easy to underestimate complexity.

I have read aviation trades that mention sightings of various but concerning ufo's that travel in a straight steak with no UFO hijinx. I wonder if it will be reveled in time for this questions time frame.

Esta pregunta resulta interesante ya que boom, una empresa privada que se encuentra desarrollando un avión comercial supersónico de tamaño intermedio (65 -68) pasajeros, planea testear su primer prototipo de menor escala a fines de 2021 y principios de 2022. en este prototípo solo cabe el piloto. Boom liberó mostró el diseño por primera vez en 2016 y tenía planeado el primer vuelo en 2017, pero todavía no haourrido.

I'm moving towards anything between 15% and 35%. On the 15% side, the CEO has started talking about 2022, and delays have been abundant in the past. On the 35% side, they have begun testing the flight vision system, which seems like maybe one of the last steps (?). Also, Laplace doesn't quite feel right for bus-waiting problems (where the longer you wait, the closer the bus is to arriving, even if you don't know when it will arrive.)

Norris. G. (2021, July 26). Boom Tests Vision System For XB-1 Supersonic Demonstrator. Aviation Week. Retrieved from https://aviationweek.com/air-transport/aircraft-propulsion/boom-tests-vision-system-xb-1-supersonic-demonstrator
Going down 3% after no new comments appeared since the points made last week.
The annoying thing about research is it often yields new information, or new ways to think about existing information. It never yields bourbon. Coming down some more.
I said I'd drop down to 5%, but I'll go to just 10% because of @cdob63's bias toward yes.
I'll go downwards more in the upcoming weeks, but comments below check out.

Possibility of early completion but indicators tell me it's too soon. I see that maiden test flights for major planes don't usually occur in the last couple months of the year, which is when the plane could be ready for testing. However, if it is completed, typically they would conduct an array of ground tests first. This may take some time. THEN, they typically proceed into flight tests.
The official line appears to now be a 2022 test flight. I'd be pretty surprised if, given the pandemic and so on, the timescale moved forwards rather at this stage.
A first flight is typically just a takeoff and landing. The real tests always come much later.
Maybe they'll finish the project early.
Updating in light of convincing news, consistent with lots of the signs that they are not on schedule. Perhaps most telling is the miss on test flights this summer.
Reuters: "Boom is building a 1/3 scale prototype of the aircraft and hopes to begin test flights in 2022".

https://uk.news.yahoo.com/startup-aims-revive-supersonic-flights-213345671.html?guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAJ7FMze3IUaiWM5-u7JmfYaJFOB09MXp41NBrLagQAEKCK68Wnn3fDbprpqI3utzIu48O64JR4bLeccDktmRyT23E1r5rgYg-IodDgO4Z1M73ZS0mjWFNjQO4goLY-F1Z_9RE50dJ5lrRpOoww-KLFStITJPHceNivDURDvyYAWm
-15, decided to lean against as there hasn't been any recent news I've seen and only 4 months left.

Gonna put some doubt based on the fact that they're still hiring a lot of positions and posting much about the development side of the aircraft, which gives me the impression that they are still in elementary stages. On the other hand, what they post does not necessarily correlate to where they are in the project and jobs are always being sought, especially since the Overture phase of the project is still far out, etc., etc.
No change

Shapiro, A. (2021, June 8). Test flights for superfast jets will 'be in the air in just a matter of months': Boom Supersonic CEO. Yahoo News. Retrieved from https://finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html
If Virgin Galactic can do it, why would Boom fail? If the US authorities are willing to promote and make Space Travel happen, why would they not engage in a new supersonic industry?
No change.

+10%. I looked at the Mojave desert's climate, and its very hot in summer, while being very tolerable in winter. This suggests that September-December would be a nice time to carry out the tests, as opposed to right now. This undoes some of my passage of time updating.

Supersonic flight has already been established as workable in both commercial and military flights. However the track record of new companies in space and supersonic flight is marred by over promising and under delivering so it is possible there is a delay till 2022.
Takes into account time passed, the current goal, and my range of possibilities I think are reasonable.

First flight of Boom’s XB-1 demonstrator could happen next year: CEO - Hemmerdinger, (2021) April, 27, Stated That: - The chief executive of Boom Supersonic has left open the possibility that the company’s supersonic demonstrator may not get airborne until next year. - CEO Blake Scholl says Boom expects the jet’s first flight will occur “around the end of this year, early next year”. \ Reference \ Hemmerdinger, J. (2021, April, 27). First flight of Boom’s XB-1 demonstrator could happen next year: CEO. Flight Global. Retrieved from https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/first-flight-of-booms-xb-1-demonstrator-could-happen-next-year-ceo/143485.article
Looking at actual pictures of the XB-1, it's difficult to say to what extent it exists: https://www.businessinsider.com/supersonic-startup-boom-unveils-xb-1-prototype-begins-flight-testing-2020-10

In a recent interview, the CEO was asked: "This plane is expected to test flight, the XB-1, at the end of this year, early next year, right?", and he answers "Yeah, that's right". If it was definitely going to happen this year, I imagine that he would have corrected the reporter. In particular, because he bullshits so much in the rest of the video and is otherwise so optimistic, the fact that he doesn't do that here is a signal. Going down ~15% based on that. https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html, 2:14 Looking at the contract with the Mojave airport https://boomsupersonic.com/news/post/boom-supersonic-mojave-supersonic-corridor, I also don't see *dates* mentioned.

The CEO just bullshits so much: https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html Also, here is the Mojave desert contract: https://boomsupersonic.com/news/post/boom-supersonic-mojave-supersonic-corridor

Raising the chances a little, but I am still not entirely convinced, partly due to thinking "what's the rush?" Given timelines extend to the end of the decade, a couple of months either way at this stage seems less important. Why rush and risk a failure? I am curious if there is an incentive to test a prototype that is not supersonic capable in order to meet the deadline (for financial reasons perhaps). For example, specific components needing further development before the prototype could physically reach supersonic speeds (e.g. an engine not powerful enough as it stands).

He seems a bit more confident here Boom's prototype experimental aircraft called the XB-1 will start test flights later this year. "That's our prototype for the Overture airliner. It rolled out last fall and it's going to be in the air in just a matter of months," Scholl said. The goal is to roll out the first Overture jet in 2025 and begin test flights in 2026. https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/test-flights-for-superfast-jets-will-be-in-the-air-in-just-a-matter-of-months-boom-supersonic-ceo-110933170.html
+5% on recent announcements of interest by United; I imagine that it correlates with Boom being on schedule

Many of the interviews from project leaders on XB-1 have very credible resumes... smart individuals probably with great rationality. Not one doubted the timeline and all cited the testing planned for this summer. Makes me question why I should go against them, who know more information than we do. We, the public, can't even predict when they'll be doing cabin and ground tests. Why wouldn't they test it this year? They have to get back to work; this is their job. They can't just wait 7 months and then decide to take off January. Then again, low sample size and huge blindspot on this topic. It does not make sense that they would start training for testing and then start 7 months later, though it is possible that they take 3 months to train, 3 months to test most things prior to flight test, and then get into the sky in early 2022.

Slotnick, D. (2021, June, 3). United Airlines announces deal with Boom Supersonic for faster-than-sound commercial flights. The Points Guy. Retrieved from https://thepointsguy.com/news/united-airlines-boom-supersonic/

Given developments and even a failure in 2021, 2022 test would be likely successful and with airlines starting to place orders, this is likely but the 75% is because there may be a delay in development which always happen but delays are less and less with developments in technology.

So apparently, a manufacturing facility is scheduled to break ground in 2022 and be completed for aircraft production around 2023. That gives the company this year and next year to flight test the XB-1 and decide on changes it wants to make before they start building the thing in 2023. They are gearing up as evidenced by recent hires and the recent deal with United Airlines. Given reports of ground testing underway a flight test of the 1/3 scale model doesn't sound so far off. The actual test flights for the full-sized Overture will be around 2026. That means XB-1 flight test can happen in either 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, or 2025. That's a 20% chance this year. However, you factor in that they want to start building by 2023. That leaves 2021 and 2022, or 50%.

As per report https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/03/united-will-buy-15-ultrafast-airplanes-from-start-up-boom-supersonic.html United Airlines has ordered 15 Boom "Ouvertures" and has an option for 35 more units. "Ouverture" is set to go into production between 2023 and 2025 (differing between sources) and will tentatively fly in 2026 for the first time. Regular service with passengers is envisioned for 2029. In total, Boom now has orders for 70 units.
Pandemic

No variation in my forecast, just to share that supersonic business jet developer Aerion has unexpectedly ceased operations after 18 years and backing by Boeing: https://www.flightglobal.com/business-aviation/supersonic-business-jet-developer-aerion-folds/143867.article
increasing very slightly per below

Increasing only very slightly (from 18 to 19%) due to the cabin pressure tests announced by the CEO in Twitter in April (h/t @probahilliby): https://twitter.com/bscholl/status/1387604718264872961 . Still puzzled why such tests do not get more publicity.

Back up because an article I read on one of the forecasters here states that testing is the Mojave Dessert is expected in mid-2021. Although that period of time is monsoon season for that region (assumption), its driest months on average are May and June - which is now. But what about the future?
Even the CEO has doubts. CEOs are most likely and should be cheerleaders for their projects. But because the aim is around the end of the year, I cannot be so sure.

Won't increase until I see evidence that they are beginning basic taxiing, systems, engines, tests, etc. I think this is crucial for an aircraft to go through and it is quite odd that it has not been reported or publicized for such a high-profile "revolutionary" aircraft. I expect to go down further if this point goes unchallenged.
Boom's CEO leaning into the hype:

From other links here sounds like they're aiming for the end of the year but they have a history of delays too. I'll give them the slight benefit of the doubt right now. I definitely think I anchored to the crowd forecast and was also too optimistic. Need to be aware of that in the future.
Not quite sure why the crowd is so optimistic here.

Thanks to @Quincel1 and @DNK89 for the reference to the Flight Global link. The lack of progress and dates going into May suggests this is unlikely. Not out of the question, but less confident than I was.
@DNK89 has found the evidence for the theory I've been suspecting might exist. CEO says the timetable has slipped, now near the end of this year or early 2022.
Listening to @Quincel1 and @DNK89 and decreasing confidence for "Yes".

CEO Blake Scholl says Boom expects the jet’s first flight will occur “around the end of this year, early next year”. https://www.flightglobal.com/airframers/first-flight-of-booms-xb-1-demonstrator-could-happen-next-year-ceo/143485.article Maybe this is a good time to reflect and revisit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_fallacy

We are 1/3rd of the way through 2021 and we have no information, set date, visible progress, or other indicator that this is happening. I don't think Boom is going to collapse or something, but the risk of delays seem very real.

-5, I think I was being too confident. May come down more but haven't looked into it much.
They don't have a date set, right? If I couldn't see the crowd forecast I'd be the other side of 50%. The certainty seems bizarre.
Time update
Didn't really understand the specifics, from what I could gather they have asked the FAA to come up with standardised procedures to expedite testing,but have been turned down.
The path from a prototype to a test flight is long and there will be many unexpected obstacles.
Progress is made in the competitor Aerion's AS2 model: https://us.cnn.com/travel/article/as2-supersonic-jet-florida-hq/index.html
Dialing this back based on BT's overly optimistic previous announcements and there not being any really information on exactly where they are in the ground testing process.
A New Supersonic Jet Is Speeding Toward Liftoff. Is The World Ready? ^ Hirschfeld (2020) November 11, stated that

Aiming for a Summer 2021 test flight gives them a fair amount of slack, so adjusting up. Still think the near-certainty being shown by the crowd is a bit unjustified though. Still a lot of moving parts which could go wrong and cause delays.
This ought o speed things up a bit. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/01/boom-supersonic-all-in-on-amazon-aws-for-aircraft-design-development.html
+5 to follow the crowd.
Raytheon subsidiary is getting involved (1), which has to be a sign of the competency of the design, AND on track for a "summer 2021" test flight (2).
Supersonic aircraft have existed for many many decades with concord, limits the amount of unknown unknowns.

Rambo, J. (2020). Boom Supersonic Rolls Out XB-1 Aircraft with Flight Hardware Components 3D Printed by VELO3D. Incognito Studio. Computer. https://incognitostudio.co.uk/boom-supersonic-rolls-out-xb-1-aircraft-with-flight-hardware-components-3d-printed-by-velo3d.html

That's their schedule and currently I don't see anything online indicating that it's not achievable. Always the risk of delays which is why I'm keeping some uncertainty but until I see a reason they wouldn't stick to their schedule I'll assume it's likely.

They have unveiled the fully assembled model and stated recently that the first test flight will be done in 2021. Moreover, they have stated in June 2020 that despite the coronavirus they remain in ”great cash position”. This is essential as their financiers and biggest potential future customers might not be.

Whilst the company are suggesting a test flight in 2021 that is it, which suggests very late in the year. Given the current climate, it probably will not take much to delay this by a couple of months into early 2022. That said, this is not quite bleeding edge technology - much of the tech is established, albeit not integrated to produce a supersonic aircraft. Interesting, the question specifically states success is only take-off and landing - no supersonic flight. That makes success slightly easier to achieve, if only to allow Boom to claim they met their target, even if it is a short loop around the airfield using components that would not support supersonic flight.

The technology is available, Boom is being driven by industry and the bureaucracy of government won't slow it down. The Boeing 737 Max went from systems checks to first flight in one year. Boeing showed pictures of it's concept jet training in August of 2016 and the first aircraft was flown 4 months later. If the XB-1 takes 3x longer than the T-X, it will have its first flight in early '21.
https://www.nasa.gov/aeroresearch/nasa-marks-continued-progress-on-x-59

Lockheed, Boeing and Northrup have all significantly reduced their historic testing timelines to meet new acquisition strategies. This innovative private company, Boom, does not have the bureaucratic red tape involved in Defense Industrial Base processes and are honing and improving on existing tech. Boom plans to conduct both ground testing and its first test flight in 2021 in the Mojave and that is highly likely given the advanced simulations that can be conducted beforehand. The rollout of the prototype is complete so its on to testing...
Recent articles show the prototype. It was just the hull. Lots of work to get it flight ready. Won't happen in 2021

I think the chance a single successful test flight before Jan 1, 2022 is pretty good. That being said, a whole lot can happen between now and then to delay a test flight. Specifically I wonder if there could potentially be funding issues considering the devastation that the Covid-19 pandemic and the resulting lockdowns have had on the travel industry.

I'm surprised at how optimistic the crowd is. They've given a press release saying they will fly in 2021, but no details of what part of the year they are targeting, and a hundred things could cause delays. Approvals may take longer than expected, manufacturing, simulations, physically getting people where they need to be. The potential for the schedule being pushed back into 2022 seems very plausible imho.

Boom is relying on the publicity that Overture presents given that other supersonic programs are also running. Overture's test flight is going to be a great way to raise future funding as it gives Boom credibility. They're going to do everything they can to fly as soon as possible. The 5% chance is that they find an engineering flaw with the design that is completely unfixable with the current design (seems quite unlikely).

Seems very likely there will be test flight, will it be successful? Based on the interest from airlines, it seems as though Boom has a sound design. I believe it is highly probable they will conduct a successful test flight.
